title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
China's currency on Tuesday hit its strongest level against the dollar in three years, posing a challenge for Beijing as it seeks to balance demand for the country's exports with surging commodity prices.

The renminbi has gained more than 10 per cent over the past year, buoyed by China's economic rebound from the coronavirus pandemic and foreign capital flows into the country.

But the currency's rise is a quandary for policymakers in China as they grapple with the impact of rising commodity prices, the risk of asset bubbles and signs that growth may be losing steam.

The onshore-traded renminbi gained 0.2 per cent to reach Rmb6.4052 per dollar on Tuesday, its highest point since June 2018. Meanwhile, the country's CSI 300 of Shanghai and Shenzhen-listed shares enjoyed its best day since July, rising 3.2 per cent.

Coronavirus digest

  • Taiwan has extended strict social distancing and contact-tracing measures by three weeks as the country's first significant outbreak of Covid-19 continues to spread.

  • Australia has reintroduced social-distancing restrictions in Melbourne following the discovery of a Covid-19 cluster. New Zealand has suspended its travel bubble with the city following the outbreak.

  • The US has issued a “do not travel” advice for Japan, urging Americans not to visit the country on account of its “very high level” of Covid-19.

  • Unanswered questions about scientists' research into an illness among Chinese miners have elevated what was once dismissed as a conspiracy theory: that Sars-Cov-2 might have leaked from a lab in Wuhan.

  • Asian countries that led the way in controlling Covid-19 last year have become laggards in efforts to vaccinate their populations. Japan has just opened its first mass vaccination sites for the elderly. (FT, Reuters, WSJ)

Thank you to those who took our poll. Fifty per cent of respondents said governments should give out incentives to encourage people to get vaccinated against Covid-19.

Follow the latest on our live blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update newsletter.

In the news

Goldman Sachs wins approval for deal with China's ICBC Goldman Sachs Asset Management has won initial approval for a wealth management joint venture with ICBC, one of China's largest banks. Goldman will hold a 51 per cent stake in the new venture, while ICBC wealth management, a subsidiary of the bank, will own the rest.

US companies amass political funding cash pile More than 40 American companies that stopped making political contributions after the riot at the US Capitol are sitting on $28m in unspent cash. It gives the political action committees of companies including 3M, American Airlines, Chevron, Citigroup, Facebook, Target and UPS an unusually large amount of dry powder to deploy ahead of next year's midterm congressional elections.

US steel lobby mobilises to preserve Donald Trump's tariffs The EU wants the 25 per cent tariffs on imported steel imposed by former president Donald Trump removed but the Biden administration is running into opposition from the powerful US steel industry with mills in states including Indiana, Ohio and Pennsylvania.

EU agrees sanctions on Belarus Brussels agreed to ratchet up sanctions against Belarus and ban its state airline from EU airports after the Minsk regime triggered global uproar by intercepting a Ryanair flight carrying an opposition activist.

Ecuador's new president strikes sombre note Conservative businessman Guillermo Lasso delivered a sombre speech to congress as he was sworn in as the country's president. Ecuador, which is struggling to repay loans to the IMF, has suffered the world's second-worst rate of excess deaths since the pandemic began.

Reddit talks cryptocurrencies Discussion on the site's main cryptocurrency forum has overtaken activity on the “meme stock” forum WallStreetBets, reflecting how many day traders have switched their focus from the equity market to digital coins in the hunt for quick returns and a bit of fun.

Shares in TikTok's main China rival tumble The market capitalisation of Kuaishou, which is backed by Chinese internet group Tencent, fell by $14bn on Tuesday in Hong Kong after the company's losses widened on growing signs that users in China are spending less on its livestreaming services.

  • Police in India have visited the local office of social media company Twitter, after its moderators labelled a tweet by the national spokesperson of the governing party as potentially misleading.

The day ahead

One year on from George Floyd's murder Joe Biden is set to meet the family of George Floyd at the White House, a year after his death triggered international protests. An FT editorial today says that the multiracial throngs that poured on to the streets after Floyd's murder have been fundamentally let down and calls on the US Senate to pass the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act.

Blinken begins Middle East visit US secretary of state Antony Blinken will begin a trip to Israel, the West Bank, Jordan and Egypt at the request of Joe Biden. In the West Bank a new generation of tech-savvy Palestinians is coming to the fore. (AP)

EU leaders meet European leaders meet for a second day. After the first day's discussions were derailed by events in Belarus, talks today will focus on the bloc's response to Covid-19 and climate change.

Economic data US sales of newly built homes are set to cool in April. (WSJ)

Vimeo lists The video service spins out of IAC and lists on Nasdaq at a valuation expected to be in the region of $10bn.

David Lawler, chief of BP America, will be speaking at day two of the inaugural Energy Source conference.

What else we're reading

The demise of the dollar? Even before the pandemic and the economic crisis it has generated, there were signs that the dollar's dominance was slipping, despite surviving at least four decades-worth of predictions of its demise. The question now is: are there circumstances in which what still amounts to dollar dominance could suddenly turn into a dollar rout?

The Fed is no longer markets' best friend Having waited for too long, the central bank faces a policy pivot — as it is hostage to a “new monetary framework” that is ill-suited for the pandemic-related structural changes to the economy. Yet the alternative of holding on to a backward-looking policy stance would threaten greater damage, writes Mohamed El-Erian.

Economic reform crucial to improving the lives of black Americans The few number of jobs created last month caught many by surprise. But another figure stood out to FT reporter Taylor Nicole Rogers: unemployment among black Americans rose to 9.7 per cent, while the aggregate jobless rate was 6.1 per cent.

  • Taylor talks on today's edition of the FT News Briefing podcast about whether economic reforms in the US will enable black Americans to recover at the same pace as the rest of the country.

Tipping on social media If the pandemic has strengthened arguments against tipping, social media seems intent on making the habit more ingrained. Twitter and Clubhouse have introduced ways to tip. YouTube is testing an “applause” feature and Facebook wants to make it easier for fans to pay. But tipping is not just a way for users to show their appreciation, says Elaine Moore, it is a way to outsource payment altogether.

Celebration of breaking the mould in later life The new podcast Growing Old Disgracefully is, according to its intro, made up of “remarkable stories told by remarkable people”. Most contributors are over the age of 70 and, as such, are people we seldom hear from in podcasting. More importantly, all have made a choice in their later years that demolishes stereotypes.

Podcast of the day

Bitcoin: ‘I'll either be rich, or wrong' When 29-year-old Sam found out that his younger brother had made £30,000 trading bitcoin, he couldn't believe what he was hearing. The self-employed musician decided to put the last £2,000 of his savings into various cryptocurrencies, hoping he could double his money. Money Clinic presenter Claer Barrett explores the highs and lows of investing in cryptocurrencies.
